conclusion: The cross-section of the cylinder is a circle with center O and radius R.
AB is a diameter of the circle.
The particle enters the field at point A with different velocities in the plane of the paper, and the direction of the velocity is perpendicular to the electric field.
The particle exits the field at point C on the circumference with a speed v_0.
The angle between AC and AB is θ = 60°.
The particle is only subjected to the electric force during its motion.
The electric force is perpendicular to the velocity of the particle.
The particle moves in a circular path due to the centripetal force provided by the electric field.
The centripetal force is given by F = mv^2/r, where m is the mass of the particle, v is the speed of the particle, and r is the radius of the circular path.
Using the kinematic equation v^2 = v_0^2 + 2ad, where a is the acceleration due to the electric force.
The acceleration due to the electric force is a = F/m = mv^2/mr.
Substituting v = v_0 and r = Rsin(θ), we get a = v_0^2/Rsin(θ).
The centripetal force is F = ma = mv_0^2/Rsin(θ).
The radius of the circular path is r = Rsin(θ).
The centripetal force is F = mv^2/r.
Substituting r = Rsin(θ), we get F = mv^2/Rsin(θ).
The speed of the particle is v = v_0.
Substituting v = v_0 and r = Rsin(θ), we get v = v_0 = mv_0^2/Rsin(θ).
The electric field strength is given by E = F/m.
Substituting F = mv^2/r and r = Rsin(θ), we get E = mv_0^2/Rsin(θ)/m = v_0^2/Rsin(θ).
The magnitude of the electric field strength is E = v_0^2/Rsin(θ).
